description:
Human gammaherpesvirus 8, also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), is a DNA virus that belongs to the Gammaherpesvirinae subfamily of the Herpesviridae family. It is the causative agent of Kaposi's sarcoma, a type of cancer that primarily affects the skin and other organs, as well as several other lymphoproliferative disorders, such as primary effusion lymphoma and multicentric Castleman's disease.

KSHV is a double-stranded DNA virus with a genome size of approximately 165 kilobase pairs. The virus is primarily transmitted through bodily fluids, such as saliva, and can establish a lifelong latent infection in the host. During latency, the virus expresses a limited set of genes, while during lytic replication, the full complement of viral genes is expressed, leading to the production of new viral particles.

KSHV infection is associated with an impaired immune system, particularly in individuals with HIV/AIDS or other immunocompromising conditions. The virus is found to be more prevalent in certain geographic regions, such as sub-Saharan Africa, and its prevalence is linked to socioeconomic and cultural factors.

Research on KSHV has provided valuable insights into the mechanisms of viral oncogenesis and the role of viral proteins in the development of Kaposi's sarcoma and other KSHV-associated malignancies. Ongoing efforts are focused on understanding the complex interplay between the virus and the host immune system, as well as the development of targeted therapies and preventive strategies.
